Title:
Addition to Sporocadaceae, Pestalotiod species associated
with Plam species from China
Keywords:
3 new species; 2 new host records; Neopestalotiopsis;
Pestalotiopsis; Sporocadaceae; Pathogenicity
Abstract:
Palm is the largest monocot group which is widely
distributed in tropical and subtropical regions. Importance of these
species vary from food sources to landscape. Therefore, identification
and characterization of pathogens associated with these hosts have
economic and ecological signifi-cant. During sample survey in 2020ï€­2021,
leaf spots on diseased Sabal mexicana, and roting tis-sues of Areca
triandra, Arenga pinnata, Dypsis leptocheilos, Washingtonia robusta were
collected from three cities in southwestern China. Fungal identification
of all isolates was performed using mor-phological characterization and
phylogenetic analysis based on the internal transcribed spacer (ITS)
region of ribosomal DNA, tub2 genes and part of the translation
elongation factor 1-alpha (TEF). In total, Six Neopestalotiopsis
isolates and 22 Pestalotiopsis isolates were obtained. These iso-lates
were further confirmed as three species were described as new species,
P. areca, P. guang-dongnsis, P. Sabal, while the other two were reported
as known species, namely N. formicarum, P. kandelicola, and the
remaining one was not be assigned to any new taxa. Kent showed that
repre-sentative isolates of the new species and new record species
isolated and identified in this study and induce weak lesions on Sabal
mexicana leaves.
